A8: Final Project

Making Something Usable

Posted by Joyce on November 22, 2022

Recap

I had planned to create an organizer to hold a tissue roll and some stationary. I would be using Rhino for designing; 3D printing a pencil holder as the axis for the tissue to rotate around it; and laser cutting the box that holds the tissue.

Design

I measured the dimensions of the tissue and my stationary to decide the exact dimension of different parts of the organizer.

Afterwards, I made all the different elements in Rhino, including the cylinder for 3D printing and the press-fit parts for laser cutting

Printing & Cutting

I then used Cura to model the cylinder and 3D printed it.

Afterwards, I headed out to the MILL to use the laser cutting machine. Since I wanted to both cut and engrave the basewood, I changed the stroke of the cutting line to 0.001 and rasterized the engrave line. I selected the "combined" option in the setting, but it turned out that I wasn't able to do both at once, but had to execute cutting and engraving saparately. I aslo learned that to thicken the engrave lines, I simply had to increase the stroke in AI.

Initially, I was planning to cut a slit on one of the rectangle piece, so I could pull the tissue out. However, I found out that the basewood was much more brittle and flimsy then I expected. I expected it to break if I cut a narrow shape, so I decided to make the slit myself using a blade knife.

Assembling

The different pieces of the box were designed to press fit togeter. For the cylinder, I fixed it to the bottom of the box using the white glue and it worked well.

I also trimmed off a small part of a side of a box so the tissue roll could come out

Here's the final piece when everything was put together. I'm glad that my tissue roll finally has a home.

Biggest thanks to Vanessa for helping with Rhino, Jalia for helping with laser printing, and Xenia for 3D printing!
